Kiros also determines that each operator has received and understands the training requirements and keeps a record of complete training for each employee with the date of the training and the method used to verify that the employee understand the subject matter.

The training program includes classroom and on job instruction with emphasis on safety and health hazards and emergency response procedures. These materials are maintained in the office area. Official training documentation will be kept in the terminal managers office. Verification that the operators understand the materials is accomplished through written tests, verbal questioning and hands-on demonstrations.

To provide a quick and efficient evacuation, practice drills should be held at least annually. These drills should mimic actual emergency situations without creating panic.

Emergency Response Program

Kiros and the contract operator have documented emergency response plans and procedures in place at the site to respond to and safety mitigates any release or accident involving butane or propane. Included in the emergency response plan are measures to be taken internally by Kiros contract operators to control the release, if possible, and to make initial notification to local responders and to Kiros headquarters.

Operator personnel at the terminal are trained to the Hazardous Materials Operations level as outlined in 29 CFR 1910.120 Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response. These employees may also perform activities under the specialist employee definition as defined by 1910.120. These personnel receive annual training on activation of the facility emergency action plan, their roles in an emergency and accident notification procedures.
 

To assure that the local municipal response agencies are familiar with Kiros emergency response procedures and copies of the all emergency action plans have been shared with and reviewed by loca

th Kiros employees.

Kiros reviews the RMP annually for non-technical changes such as emergency contact information. Kiros also reviews the RMP when there is a significant change in offloading design or site layout; there is a change in equipment, hazardous materials, or processes that affect evacuation routes or emergency response activities; or new hazards are introduced that may require special actions or responses, and at a minimum of at least every three years.

Process Specific Information

A copy of the up-to-date Safety Data Sheets (SDS) for Liquid Petroleum Gas (LPG) Butane and Propane are available to staff at all times and in Appendix B.

Butane (an LPG) is a gas at normal temperature and pressures, it is commonly liquefied by is a direct relationship between ambient temperature and pressure inside the storage containers. As the ambient temperature increases, the pressure of the container increases proportionately. According to NFPA 58, 1998 Edition, table B-1.2.1, commercial butane when heated to a temperature of 105 °F will produce a pressure of 41 pounds per square inches, gauge (psig). NFPA 58, 1998 Edition, Table 2-2.2.2 sets the current minimum design pressure for an ASME tank at 250 pounds per square inch, absolute (psia). This design allows for a maximum vapor pressure of 215 psia at 100°F. The discharge piping for pumps and compressors is currently designed to 350 psi and vapor piping is designed for 250 psi (or 125 psi for vapor piping subject to pressures of not more than 125 psi), according to NFPA 58, 1998 Edition, 3-2.10.2. The minimum temperatures are determined by the steel used in the design of the rail car tanks and piping.

Propane (an LPG) is a gas at normal temperatures and pressures, it is commonly liquified by storing it in a closed container at pressures higher than its equilibrium vapor pressure. There is a direct relationship between ambient temperature and pressure inside the storage containers. As the ambient temperature increa

t, control, and response among onsite and offsite personnel.

Kiros, or agents/contract operators working on behalf of Kiros, off loads liquid petroleum gas (LPG) from approximately 29,000 to 30,500-gallon capacity rail cars to 8,000 to 15,000-gallon tanker trucks. Trained on this plan and NRPA-58, Kiros employees are present during all offloading of butane and propane from a railcar to a tanker truck.

Kiros worst-case scenario is failure of one of the 30,500-gallon capacity rail cars, which could potentially result in a vapor cloud explosion with an approximately a radius of 0.40 miles. The resulting distance to the endpoint extends off site, and public receptors are within distance to the endpoint (Figure 3). The alternative release scenario is a pull-away or piping break explosion. In either case, an estimated maximum of 1,750 gallons of LPG would be released. The resulting distance to the endpoint extends off site with an approximate radius of 0.10 miles, and public receptors are within distance to the endpoint (Figure 4).

Kiros complies with Environmental Protection Agencys (EPA) accident prevention rule, the OSHA PSM standard, and all applicable state and local codes and regulations. The rail cars are designed and maintained in accordance with NFPA-58 and state laws.
 
Kiros has never experienced an accident involving LPG that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place at the Site.

In the event of an emergency involving LPG, it is Kiros policy to notify the Hanover Township Fire District No. 3 (973-267-5659 or 911) and request that they help respond to the emergency. Kiros will have coordinated a response plan with the fire department and invites the fire department to inspect the off-loading system and conduct a joint exercise with them to respond to any emergencies onsite.

There are currently no planned construction changes to improve the safety of the Site. However, continual training takes place wi

Morristown Facility

Introductions and Policies

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan (RMP) is to describe measures to be implemented by Kiros Energy Marketing ULC (Kiros) to prepare to respond to emergency situations in a safe, effective, and timely manner to mitigate impacts to human health and the environment. The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies for Kiros operating near the corner of East Frederick Place and Ridgedale Avenue, Cedar Knolls, New Jersey 07927 (hereafter referred to as the Site), complies with NFPA-58 requirements for LPG storage, and it is the policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws. If an emergency were to occur, it is Kiros policy to notify the Hanover Township Fire District No. 3 (973-267-5659 or 911) and local emergency planning committee (LEPC) and request that they respond to the emergency.

This plan has been prepared to meet the requirements of Title 40, Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68 (40 CFR Part 68); the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard, 29 CFR Part 1910.119; the OSHA Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response Standard (HAZWOPER), 29 CFR 1910.132; Personal Protective Equipment General Requirements, 29 CFR 1910.133; Personal Protective Equipment Eye and face protection, 29 CFR 1910.134; Personal Protective Equipment Respiratory protection, 29 CFR 1910.138; Personal Protective Equipment Hand protection, 29 CFR 1910.120; the OSHA Hazard Communication Standard, 29 CFR 1910.1200.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

Kiros, or agents/contract operators working on behalf of Kiros, will not conduct any non-clerical activities inside any onsite buildings. Kiros will be offloading butane and propane from stationary rail cars into tanker trucks (and vice versa). Rail cars and tanker trucks will be managed to protect the humans and the environment.
